facts.text: Field No. 1129/477 measuring five bighas and thirteen biswas situated in Kilokri was an evacuee property under the management of the managing officer.

anchor.surface_text: Field No. 1129/477 measuring five bighas and thirteen biswas situated in Kilokri was an evacuee property and as such was under the management of the managing officer.

facts.text: The property was acquired by the Central Government under the Displaced Persons Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That property was acquired by the Central Government under the Displaced Persons Act, 1954.  For the sake of companyvenience we shall refer to that property hereinafter as evacuee property.

facts.text: The property was sold by public auction on January 2, 1961 and purchased by PW 17 Ashwani Kumar Dutt for Rs. 7,600.

anchor.surface_text: The same was sold by public auction on January 2, 1961 and purchased by PW 17 Ashwani Kumar Dutt for a sum of Rs. 7,600.

facts.text: Provisional delivery of the property was given to the vendee on October 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Provisional delivery of that property was given to the vendee on October 10, 1961.

facts.text: The sale certificate was issued on February 8, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The sale certificate was issued on February 8, 1962.

facts.text: Actual delivery was given on June 22, 1962 as per the warrant issued by PW 5 Khushi Ram, the managing officer, effected by PW 11 Sham Das Kanungo.

anchor.surface_text: The actual delivery was given on June 22, 1962 as per the warrant issued by PW 5. Khushi Ram, the managing officer. The said delivery was effected by PW It  Sham Das Kanungo.

facts.text: On July 1, 1962, PW 17 and his father PW 19 R. P. Dutt went to the field with PW 16 Gopal Das, PW 15 Nand Lal and B. N. Acharya with a tractor to level the land.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1962 when PW 17 and his father PW 19, R. P. Dutt went to the field with PW 16, Gopal Das, PW 15 Nand Lal and one B. N. Acharya with a trac- tor to level the land,

facts.text: Appellants came armed with spears and lathis, attacked the complainants' party and caused injuries to PW 17, PW 19 and the tractor driver B. N. Acharya.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants came armed with spears and lathis attacked the companyplainants party and caused injuries to PWs 17 and 19 and the tractor driver, B. N. Acharya.

facts.text: Jamuna (DW 3) was the tenant in the land for over thirty years; his tenancy was never terminated.

anchor.surface_text: Their case is that their relation Jamuna  DW 3  was the tenant in the land for over thirty years. His tenancy was never terminated.

facts.text: Jamuna had raised crops in the field in question.

anchor.surface_text: He had raised crops in the field in question. There was numberdelivery on June 22, 1962.

facts.text: On the day prior to the occurrence (June 30, 1962), PW 17 and PW 19 tried to intimidate Jamuna to come to terms and deliver possession peacefully.

anchor.surface_text: On the day prior to the occurrence, PWs 17 and 19 tried to intimidate Jamuna to companye to terms with them and to peacefully deliver possession of the property to them.

facts.text: PW 19 was armed with an unlicensed pistol on July 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: At that time PW 19 was armed with an unlicensed pistol.

facts.text: Appellants asked the complainant party to clear out of the field, and when refused, pushed them and used minimum force to throw them out.

anchor.surface_text: It is at this stage that the appellants who are near relations of Jamuna went to the field and asked the companyplainant party to clear out of the field. When they refused to do so,

facts.text: Courts below accepted prosecution version and convicted appellants under ss. 447, 324 read with 149 and 148 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below have accepted the prosecution version both as regards possession as well as to the manner in which the incident took place. The appellants have been companyvicted under ss. 447, 324 read with 149 and 148 I.P.C.

facts.text: Jamuna in possession of the field till June 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: DW 3, Jamuna, in his evidence deposed that he had been in possession of that field as a tenant for over thirty years. ... The companyrts below have also proceeded on the basis that Jamuna was in possession of the field till June 22, 1962.

facts.text: At the time of delivery on June 22, 1962, Jamuna was not present; no evidence he was aware.

anchor.surface_text: Even according to the prosecution version, at the time of that delivery Jamuna was number present. There is also numberevidence to show that Jamuna was aware of the alleged delivery.

facts.text: Crops grown by Jamuna were in a portion of the field at time of alleged delivery; valued at Rs. 60, deposited by PW 17.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that as a token of the delivery, some ploughing was done at the time of the alleged delivery. At this stage it is also necessary to mention that at the time of the alleged delivery, crops grown by Jamuna were there in a portion of the field.

facts.text: Jamuna continued in possession even after June 22, 1962; delivery invalid in law.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is obvious that the alleged delivery has numberlegal force. In the eye of the law it is number-est. Hence Jamuna companytinued to be in possession of the field in question even after the so-called delivery on Juno 22, 1962.

facts.text: PWs 17 and 19 aware that delivery was paper delivery; threatened Jamuna on June 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It is seen from the evidence of DW 3, Jamuna, which evidence was number even challenged in cross-examination, that PWs 17 and 19 were aware of the fact that the purported delivery on June 22, 1962 was merely a paper delivery.

facts.text: Police assistance obtained at time of delivery on June 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This is borne out by the fact that at the time of the alleged delivery on June 22, 1962, police assistance was applied for and obtained.

facts.text: No visit to field by complainant or men between June 22 and July 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It is number the case of the prosecution that between June 22 and July 1, 1962 the companyplainant or his men -had been to the field in question.

facts.text: Injuries caused to PW 17, PW 19 and Acharya were simple injuries.

anchor.surface_text: The injuries caused by them were held to be simple injuries.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 26, 1965 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 266-D of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 26, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Revision No. 266-D of 1964.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside conviction, acquits appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the companyviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.

issues.text: whether the appellants have established satisfactorily the right of private defence pleaded by them

anchor.surface_text: Two questions that arise for decision in this appeal by special leave are  1  whether the appellants have established satisfactorily the right of private defence pleaded by them and  2  if they had that right,

issues.text: if they had that right, have they exceeded the same

anchor.surface_text: Two questions that arise for decision in this appeal by special leave are  1  whether the appellants have established satisfactorily the right of private defence pleaded by them and  2  if they had that right, have they exceeded the same ? The prosecution case is as follows

issues.text: as to who was in possession of the field in dispute on the date of the occurrence, i.e., on July 1, 1962

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this case is as to who was in possession of the field in dispute on the date of the occurrence, i.e., on July 1, 1962. For deciding that question it is necessary to find out as to who was in possession

issues.text: whether there was any lawful delivery of that field on June 22, 1962

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we have to see whether there was any lawful delivery of that field on June 22, 1962. At this stage it is necessary to recapitulate that the field in question had been sold by the managing officer

issues.text: whether PW 5, the managing officer was competent to evict Jamuna

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether PW 5, the managing officer was competent to evict Jamuna. We fail to see how he could have done it. He had no interest in the land in question on June 22, 1962.

issues.text: whether the purported delivery is valid in law

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether the purported delivery is valid in law. Normally before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated

issues.text: whether the delivery in question was effected under S. 19 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Before the courts below it was pleaded on behalf of the prosecution...that the delivery in question was effected under S. 19 of the Act. Section 19 ,to the extent it is material for our present purpose, reads thus...

issues.text: whether on the basis of the undisputed facts as well as the facts found by the High Court, the defence can be said to have made out the plea of defence of property

anchor.surface_text: We have no to see whether on the basis of the undisputed facts as well as the facts found by the High Court, the defence can be said to have made out the plea of defence of property advanced on their behalf.

arguments.court_reasoning: Property no longer evacuee; no action under sub-ss 1-2; managing officer no power

arguments.claim: Even if Jamuna in possession, had enough time to recourse to public authorities post June 22 delivery, no right of private defence

arguments.court_reasoning: Unaware of delivery; sudden invasion on July 1

arguments.claim: Jamuna in possession till June 22, 1962; no lawful delivery thereafter

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this case is as to who was in possession of the field in dispute on the date of the occurrence, i.e., on July 1, 1962. For deciding that question it is necessary to find out as to who was in possession

arguments.claim: Managing officer had no competence to evict Jamuna or issue delivery warrant on June 22 as property sold earlier

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether PW 5, the managing officer was competent to evict Jamuna. We fail to see how he could have done it. He had no interest in the land in question on June 22, 1962.

arguments.claim: Tenant eviction requires termination of tenancy and court process; no landlord right to evict by force

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether the purported delivery is valid in law. Normally before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated and the eviction should be done through a companyrt of companypetent jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: S.19 DPA inapplicable as property ceased to be evacuee; no prior action under sub-ss 1-2

anchor.surface_text: The above provisions apply only to properties which are under .the companytrol of the managing officers or managing companyporations. They do number apply to properties which have ceased to be evacuee properties. Further, it is number the prosecution case that any action under sub-ss. 1 and 2 of S. 19 had ever been taken against Jamuna.

arguments.claim: PWs 17,19 aware delivery was paper delivery; threatened Jamuna; no visit to field between June 22-July 1

anchor.surface_text: It is seen from the evidence of DW 3, Jamuna, which evidence was number even challenged in cross-examination, that PWs 17 and 19 were aware of the fact that the purported delivery on June 22, 1962 was merely a paper delivery.

arguments.claim: Complainants were trespassers and unlawful assembly on July 1; appellants had right of private defence of property under ss.97,99 IPC

anchor.surface_text: From the proved facts, it is evident that PWs 17 and 19 had gone to the field with their friends, PW 19 being armed with deadly -weapon, with a view to intimidate Jamuna and to assert their -possession. Therefore they were clearly guilty of criminal trespass.

arguments.claim: Appellants did not exceed right of private defence; simple injuries

anchor.surface_text: The injuries caused by them were held to be simple injuries.

arguments.claim: Plea of private defence can be considered even if not in s.342 CrPC if arises from record; burden by preponderance

anchor.surface_text: Though the appellants in their statement under s. 342 Cr.P.C. denied having been present at the scene of occurrence or having caused injuries to any one, the plea taken on their behalf at all stages was one of private defence.

arguments.claim: Settled possession entitles defence even against true owner; paper delivery ineffective against tenant

anchor.surface_text: It is true that numberone including the true owner has a right to dispossess the trespasser by force if the trespasser is in settled possession of the land and in such a case unless he is evicted in due companyrse of law,

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Jai Dev, Horam, Sangappa, Mooka Nadar

holdings.text: Jamuna continued to be in possession of the field even after the delivery on June 22, 1962 as the delivery was invalid in law.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is obvious that the alleged delivery has no legal force. In the eye of the law it is non-est. Hence Jamuna continued to be in possession of the field in question even after the so-called delivery on June 22, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delivery lacked legal force as managing officer had no authority post-sale, no termination of tenancy, no S.19 compliance; crops present, Jamuna absent/unaware.

holdings.text: The purported delivery on June 22, 1962 was invalid in law.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether the purported delivery is valid in law. Normally before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated and the eviction should be done through a court of competent jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenant eviction requires tenancy termination and court process; no landlord right to evict by force; cites Lallu Yeshwant Singh.

holdings.text: Managing officer PW 5 was not competent to evict Jamuna or issue delivery warrant on June 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether PW 5, the managing officer was competent to evict Jamuna. We fail to see how he could have done it. He had no interest in the land in question on June 22, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property sold earlier, government interest alienated; managing officer gave landlord's possession; no provision to deal with non-evacuee property.

holdings.text: Delivery not effected under S.19 of Displaced Persons Act as property ceased to be evacuee and no prior actions under sub-ss.(1)-(2).

anchor.surface_text: The above provisions apply only to properties which are under the control of the managing officers or managing corporations. They do not apply to properties which have ceased to be evacuee properties. Further, it is not the prosecution case that any action under sub-ss. (1) and (2) of S. 19 had ever been taken against Jamuna.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.19 applies only to evacuee properties under control; requires prior show cause/eviction steps; power under sub-s.(3) strict and conditional.

holdings.text: Plea of private defence can be considered even if not specifically pleaded in statement under S.342 Cr.P.C., if arises from record.

anchor.surface_text: Though the appellants in their statement under s. 342 Cr.P.C. denied having been present at the scene of occurrence or having caused injuries to any one, the plea taken on their behalf at all stages was one of private defence. ... It is well-settled that even if an accused does not plead selfdefence, it is open to the court to consider such a plea if the same arises from the material on record-see In re Jogali.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Basis laid in cross-examination and defence evidence; cites In re Jogali; burden discharged by preponderance of probabilities.

holdings.text: Complainant party (PWs 17,19 and others) committed criminal trespass and constituted unlawful assembly on July 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: From the proved facts, it is evident that PWs 17 and 19 had gone to the field with their friends, PW 19 being armed with deadly -weapon, with a view to intimidate Jamuna and to assert their -possession. Therefore they were clearly guilty of criminal trespass. They also constituted an unlawful assembly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Paper delivery ineffective; no settled possession by PW17 (stray acts); armed intimidation to dispossess tenant in possession.

holdings.text: Appellants had right of private defence of property under Ss.97 and 99 IPC and did not exceed it.

anchor.surface_text: The law relating to defence of property is, set out in s. 97 IPC, which says that every person has a right, subject to the restrictions contained in s. 99, ... Section 99 of the Code lays down that there is no right of private defence in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jamuna in settled possession; sudden trespass unaware of invalid delivery; simple injuries; no excess harm; no time for authorities.

holdings.text: Appellants did not exceed right of private defence as injuries were simple.

anchor.surface_text: The injuries caused by them were held to be simple injuries.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution accepted simple nature; force minimum to eject trespassers; within limits of S.99.

holdings.text: Person in settled possession can defend against true owner without court eviction; paper/symbolic delivery ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that no one including the true owner has a right to dispossess the trespasser by force if the trespasser is in settled possession of the land and in such a case unless he is evicted in due course of law, ... The possession which a trespasser is entitled to defend against the rightful owner must be a settled possession extending over a sufficiently long period and acquiesced in by the true owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jamuna tenant >30 years, crops, unchallenged; stray ploughing/police not interrupt; cites Jai Dev, Horam, Sangappa, Mooka Nadar.

holdings.text: No time to recourse to public authorities; sudden invasion entitled private defence.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the prosecution that even assuming that Jamuna was in possession of the field in view of the delivery that had taken place on June 22, 1962, he and his relations had enough time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities ... The case of Jamuna and the appellants was that they were unaware of the alleged delivery on June 22, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unaware/absent at delivery; prior conversation assumed continued possession; surprise attack on July 1.

holdings.text: Burden on accused for private defence discharged by preponderance of probabilities from record.

anchor.surface_text: The burden of establishing that plea is on the accused and that burden can be discharged by showing preponderance of probabilities in favour of that plea on the basis of the material on record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard less than beyond reasonable doubt; material on record suffices.

holdings.text: Appellants acquitted; convictions under Ss.447, 324/149, 148 IPC set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right of private defence established and not exceeded; no offences committed.

precedents.citation: In re Jogali Bhaigo Naiks and another 1

anchor.surface_text: if the same arises from the material on record-see In re Jogali Bhaigo Naiks and another 1 . The burden of establishing that plea is on the accused and that

precedents.case_name: In re Jogali Bhaigo Naiks and another
precedents.cited_proposition: even if an accused does not plead self-defence, it is open to the court to consider such a plea if the same arises from the material on record

precedents.citation: Lallu Yeshwant Singh v. Rao Jagdish Singh and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The law on the subject was explained by this Court in Lallu Yeshwant Singh v. Rao Jagdish Singh and others 1 . Therefore, it is clear that PW 17 who had become the owner of the land long before June 22, 1962 could not have evicted Jamuna from the land in the manner alleged.

precedents.case_name: Lallu Yeshwant Singh v. Rao Jagdish Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated and the eviction should be done through a court of competent jurisdiction; no landlord has any right to throw out his tenant from his holding

precedents.citation: Jai Dev v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: In Jai Dev v. State of Punjab 1 , this Court while dealing with the right of defence of property and person observed (at p. 500) In appreciating the validity of the appellants argument, it would be necessary to recall the basic assump- 1 1963 3 S.C.R. 489.

precedents.case_name: Jai Dev v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: underlying the law of self-defence: citizen entitled to defend person and property if sudden assault and immediate state aid not available; violence must not be disproportionate
precedents.cited_holding: where an individual citizen or his property is faced with a danger and immediate aid from the State machinery is not readily available, the individual citizen is entitled to protect himself and his property

anchor.surface_text: In Horam and others v. Rex 1 , a division bench of the Allahabad High Court observed that where a trespasser enters upon the land of another, the person in whom the rightful possession is vested, while the trespasser is in the process of acquiring possession, may turn the trespasser out of the land by force 1 50 Cr. L.J. 868.

precedents.cited_proposition: where a trespasser enters upon the land of another, the person in rightful possession may turn the trespasser out by force if warranted by the situation; covered by private defence ss. 96 to 105 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Similar was the view taken by a division bench of the Hyderabad High Court in Sangappa and Ors. v. State 2 . Therein it was held that if somebody enters on the land of a person who does not acquiesce in the trespass he would still retain possession of the land 2 I.L.R. 1955 Hyderabad 406.

precedents.cited_proposition: person in possession who does not acquiesce in trespass retains possession and can resist trespassers with force of arms using friends; not unlawful assembly; but if acquiesces then later reclamation may be

anchor.surface_text: The burden of establishing that plea is on the accused and that burden can be discharged by showing preponderance of probabilities in favour of that plea on the basis of the material on record.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.

This takes us to the question whether the purported delivery is valid in law. Normally before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated and the eviction should be done through a court of competent jurisdiction.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.
The next question is whether PW 5, the managing officer was competent to evict Jamuna. We fail to see how he could have done it. He had no interest in the land in question on June 22, 1962.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.

The above provisions apply only to properties which are under the control of the managing officers or managing corporations. They do not apply to properties which have ceased to be evacuee properties. Further, it is not the prosecution case that any action under sub-ss. (1) and (2) of S. 19 had ever been taken against Jamuna.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: From the proved facts, it is evident that PWs 17 and 19 had gone to the field with their friends, PW 19 being armed with deadly -weapon, with a view to intimidate Jamuna and to assert their -possession. anchor.surface_text: The law relating to defence of property is, set out in s. 97 IPC, which says that every person has a right, subject to the restrictions contained in s. 99, ... Section 99 of the Code lays down that there is no right of private defence in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.
